verses.text: An oracle concerning Moab: Ar in Moab is ruined, destroyed in a night! Kir in Moab is ruined, destroyed in a night!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 13–23
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–23:18 Isaiah prophesies concerning the day of the Lord and what it means for the nations. Babylon and Assyria are treated together in the first oracle (13:1–14:27) because Babylon became the crown jewel of the Assyrian Empire. Assyrian kings had themselves crowned as kings of this renowned city. Babylon was regarded as an epitome of religion and culture, and as such Babylon represents the kingdoms of this world. Peter and John continue to use Babylon as a symbol for ungodly nations (1 Pet. 5:13; Rev. 14:8; 16:19; 17:1–18:24).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15–16
rsbNotes.text: 15:1–16:14 This oracle of judgment against Moab was probably delivered around the time of Sargon’s defeat of Moab in 715 b.c. See also 11:14; 25:10; Jer. 48; Ezek. 25:8–11; Amos 2:1–3; Zeph. 2:8–11. The oracle concerns Moab’s distress (ch. 15) and the response to Moab’s distress (ch. 16).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:1
rsbNotes.text:
15:1 oracle. See note 13:1.

Moab. Moab was a nation east of the Dead Sea, between the Ammonites and the Edomites. Her relations with Judah were often tense.

Ar . . . Kir. The city of Ar was on the Arnon River, and Kir was the capital of Moab.

verses.text: Dibon goes up to its temple, to its high places to weep; Moab wails over Nebo and Medeba. Every head is shaved and every beard cut off.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:2
rsbNotes.text:
15:2 Dibon . . . high places. Dibon was a site north of the Arnon River devoted to the worship of the Moabite god Chemosh.

Nebo . . . Medeba. Nebo was a village north of the Arnon River, not far from the mountain where Moses went to look at the Promised Land (Deut. 34:1). Medeba was five miles to the southeast.

baldness. The customs of mourning included cutting the hair and shaving.

verses.text: In the streets they wear sackcloth; on the roofs and in the public squares they all wail, prostrate with weeping.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:3
rsbNotes.text:
15:3 streets. See note 24:11.

sackcloth . . . tears. These were customs of mourning (v. 2; 22:12; Jer. 4:8; 41:5; 48:20, 34; Lam. 2:10).

verses.text: Heshbon and Elealeh cry out, their voices are heard all the way to Jahaz. Therefore the armed men of Moab cry out, and their hearts are faint.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:4
rsbNotes.text:
15:4 Heshbon and Elealeh. These two towns were close together, about six miles north of Medeba (v. 2). Heshbon was captured by Israel under Moses (Num. 21:23–26).

Jahaz. Located on the Arnon River, about twenty miles south of Heshbon (Num. 21:23; Jer. 48:34).

verses.text: My heart cries out over Moab; her fugitives flee as far as Zoar, as far as Eglath Shelishiyah. They go up the way to Luhith, weeping as they go; on the road to Horonaim they lament their destruction.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:5
rsbNotes.text:
15:5 My heart cries. Isaiah has noticeably more sympathy for Moab, Ruth’s homeland (16:11), than for the other nations.

Zoar. The Moabites flee to Zoar, as their forefather Lot had done (Gen. 19:23–30).

Luhith . . . Horonaim. Unidentified cities probably close to Zoar (Jer. 48:3, 5, 34).

verses.text: The waters of Nimrim are dried up and the grass is withered; the vegetation is gone and nothing green is left.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:6
rsbNotes.text: 15:6 waters of Nimrim. Possibly a seasonal stream southeast of the Dead Sea (Jer. 48:34).

verses.text: So the wealth they have acquired and stored up they carry away over the Ravine of the Poplars.
Their outcry echoes along the border of Moab; their wailing reaches as far as Eglaim, their lamentation as far as Beer Elim.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:7
rsbNotes.text: 15:7 Brook of the Willows. This may be the Zered River on the border between Moab and Edom (v. 8).

verses.text: Dimon's waters are full of blood, but I will bring still more upon Dimon - a lion upon the fugitives of Moab and upon those who remain in the land.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 15:9
rsbNotes.text:
15:9 Dibon . . . blood. A city on the Arnon River.

a lion. The fugitives go from trouble to trouble (cf. Amos 5:19) in their flight southward. They finally turn to Judah in the west for asylum (16:1–5).

verses.text: Send lambs as tribute to the ruler of the land, from Sela, across the desert, to the mount of the Daughter of Zion.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:1
rsbNotes.text:
16:1 Send the lamb. The Moabites were shepherds (Num. 32:3, 4), and could send lambs as tokens of their submission (cf. 2 Kin. 3:4).

from Sela. The fugitives were either at Sela, a naturally fortified site in Edom or at a mountain stronghold (Hebrew sela‘ means “rock,” or “cliff”). The tribute is sent from their outpost to Judah.

Zion. See note 1:8.

verses.text: Like fluttering birds pushed from the nest, so are the women of Moab at the fords of the Arnon.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:2
rsbNotes.text: 16:2 birds . . . at the fords. The fugitives became refugees fleeing to the south (15:8, 9).

verses.text: "Give us counsel, render a decision. Make your shadow like night- at high noon. Hide the fugitives, do not betray the refugees.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:3
rsbNotes.text: 16:3 shade. The verse requests protection from the heat of the day.

verses.text: Let the Moabite fugitives stay with you; be their shelter from the destroyer." The oppressor will come to an end, and destruction will cease; the aggressor will vanish from the land.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:4
rsbNotes.text: 16:4 oppressor . . . he who tramples underfoot. Assyria.

verses.text: In love a throne will be established; in faithfulness a man will sit on it- one from the house of David- one who in judging seeks justice and speeds the cause of righteousness.
We have heard of Moab's pride- her overweening pride and conceit, her pride and her insolence- but her boasts are empty.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:5
rsbNotes.text:
16:5 in steadfast love. God had made a covenant with David (55:3; 2 Sam. 22:51; Ps. 89:28; see note 54:8). In Jesus, the Son of David, the nations find shelter (Acts 15:16, 17).

throne . . . tent of David. Hope lies in Yahweh and in His promises to David (9:2–7; 11:1–9; Amos 9:11, 12).

verses.text: Therefore the Moabites wail, they wail together for Moab. Lament and grieve for the men of Kir Hareseth.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:7
rsbNotes.text: 16:7 See “God Sees and Knows: Divine Omniscience” at Prov. 15:3.

verses.text: The fields of Heshbon wither, the vines of Sibmah also. The rulers of the nations have trampled down the choicest vines, which once reached Jazer and spread toward the desert. Their shoots spread out and went as far as the sea.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:8
rsbNotes.text:
16:8 Heshbon . . . Sibmah. These places were not far apart (15:4; Jer. 48:32).

vine. The imagery of the vineyard (5:1–7) is applied here to Moab.

Jazer . . . the sea. Jazer was the extreme north of Moabite territory.

verses.text: So I weep, as Jazer weeps, for the vines of Sibmah. O Heshbon, O Elealeh, I drench you with tears! The shouts of joy over your ripened fruit and over your harvests have been stilled.
Joy and gladness are taken away from the orchards; no one sings or shouts in the vineyards; no one treads out wine at the presses, for I have put an end to the shouting.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:9
rsbNotes.text:
16:9 I weep . . . I drench. Isaiah is moved by the desolation of the fine vineyards.

Elealeh. See 15:4.

verses.text: My heart laments for Moab like a harp, my inmost being for Kir Hareseth.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:11
rsbNotes.text: 16:11 my inner parts moan . . . my inmost self. This describes deeply felt sorrow (v. 9; 21:3, 4; cf. Jer. 48:36). See note 15:5.

verses.text: When Moab appears at her high place, she only wears herself out; when she goes to her shrine to pray, it is to no avail.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:12
rsbNotes.text: 16:12 high place . . . sanctuary. See note 15:2.

verses.text: This is the word the LORD has already spoken concerning Moab.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:13
rsbNotes.text: 16:13 the Lord spoke. This summary regarding Moab’s distress is in prose form. Either it is a revelation in the past or a reference to the oracles in 15:1–9 or 15:1–16:12.

verses.text: But now the LORD says: "Within three years, as a servant bound by contract would count them, Moab's splendor and all her many people will be despised, and her survivors will be very few and feeble."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 16:14
rsbNotes.text:
16:14 In three years. The desolation of Moab is at hand. Perhaps this is a reference to the quelling of the rebellion against Sargon, king of Assyria, in 715 b.c.

glory. The prophetic word applies to all who exalt themselves and trouble the people of God. Salvation is in the Messiah (v. 5), but those who seek refuge for political or economic reasons will not find shelter in Zion.

verses.text: An oracle concerning Damascus: "See, Damascus will no longer be a city but will become a heap of ruins.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17
rsbNotes.text: 17:1–14 This oracle of judgment concerning Damascus may be dated to the Syro-Ephraimite crisis of 734–732 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:1
rsbNotes.text:
17:1 oracle. See 13:1.

Damascus. Besides being the capital of Syria, it was also the commercial hub along the trade routes between Mesopotamia, Egypt and Arabia. Damascus was captured by Tiglath-pileser III in 732 b.c.

verses.text: The cities of Aroer will be deserted and left to flocks, which will lie down, with no one to make them afraid.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:2
rsbNotes.text: 17:2 Aroer. This city was located on the Arnon River (2 Kin. 10:32, 33). Syria’s political control extended at times to the Arnon.

verses.text: The fortified city will disappear from Ephraim, and royal power from Damascus; the remnant of Aram will be like the glory of the Israelites," declares the LORD Almighty.
"In that day the glory of Jacob will fade; the fat of his body will waste away.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:3
rsbNotes.text:
17:3 fortress . . . Ephraim. The “strong cities” (v. 9) of Israel were already weakened by 732 b.c. (9:1 note) and ceased to exist in 722 b.c.

remnant. Unlike Israel, Syria has no remnant.

verses.text: It will be as when a reaper gathers the standing grain and harvests the grain with his arm- as when a man gleans heads of grain in the Valley of Rephaim.
Yet some gleanings will remain, as when an olive tree is beaten, leaving two or three olives on the topmost branches, four or five on the fruitful boughs," declares the LORD, the God of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:5
rsbNotes.text: 17:5 Valley of Rephaim. A lush valley southwest of Jerusalem, it was the gateway to the western plains (Josh. 15:8; 18:16; 2 Sam. 5:18, 22; 1 Chr. 14:9).

verses.text: In that day men will look to their Maker and turn their eyes to the Holy One of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:7
rsbNotes.text:
17:7 man. The faithful remnant look to their Creator.

Maker. The prophet contrasts the works of God with those of His creatures. See note 2:8.

verses.text: They will not look to the altars, the work of their hands, and they will have no regard for the Asherah poles and the incense altars their fingers have made.
In that day their strong cities, which they left because of the Israelites, will be like places abandoned to thickets and undergrowth. And all will be desolation.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:8
rsbNotes.text: 17:8 Asherim. The Canaanite goddess Asherah was a fertility goddess, symbolized by sacred groves and poles (27:9; Ex. 34:13; Deut. 16:21; Judg. 2:13).

verses.text: You have forgotten God your Savior; you have not remembered the Rock, your fortress. Therefore, though you set out the finest plants and plant imported vines,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:10
rsbNotes.text:
17:10 forgotten . . . have not remembered. This expression describes apostasy (Deut. 4:9, 23; 8:11, 14, 19; 32:18).

Rock. See note 8:14, 15.

refuge. The Lord alone is the strength of His people (25:4; 27:5), in contrast to military and political solutions (v. 9; 23:11, 14; 30:2).

pleasant plants . . . stranger. This reference probably points to Canaanite fertility rituals. Israel had cultivated relations with her neighbors and had adapted their ways.

verses.text: though on the day you set them out, you make them grow, and on the morning when you plant them, you bring them to bud, yet the harvest will be as nothing in the day of disease and incurable pain.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:11
rsbNotes.text:
17:11 make them grow. Perhaps this alludes to a pagan practice in which potted plants were forced to sprout in order to secure fertile crops.

harvest. The end will bring nothing but disaster.

verses.text: Oh, the raging of many nations- they rage like the raging sea! Oh, the uproar of the peoples- they roar like the roaring of great waters!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:12
rsbNotes.text: 17:12 thundering of the sea . . . mighty waters. The destructive power of the nations appears to be like that of the “seas” and “mighty waters” (8:7 note). In ancient Near Eastern myths the sea represents chaos and death (Ezek. 28:2; 32:2 and notes).

verses.text: Although the peoples roar like the roar of surging waters, when he rebukes them they flee far away, driven before the wind like chaff on the hills, like tumbleweed before a gale.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:13
rsbNotes.text:
17:13 chaff . . . whirling dust. To be driven away as chaff (cf. 29:5; 41:15, 16; Ps. 83:13) reveals a lack of life, value, and stability.

mountains. Grain is winnowed on windy hilltops.

verses.text: In the evening, sudden terror! Before the morning, they are gone! This is the portion of those who loot us, the lot of those who plunder us.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 17:14
rsbNotes.text: 17:14 terror. An unforeseen series of troubles (24:17, 18), appear on the day of the Lord’s wrath (22:5). The Lord still protects His people. He is Immanuel (7:14 note; 8:8 note; 8:10 note), who repays the nations for the evil done to His people.

verses.text: Woe to the land of whirring wings along the rivers of Cush,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:1
rsbNotes.text:
18:1 Ah. See note 1:4.

land of whirring wings. This may mean either a land of “many insects” or “many ships” (so ancient translations).

Cush. The biblical Ethiopia is the remote region of southern Egypt and beyond, including Nubia, south of the fourth cataract of the Nile. The Nubian Shabako ruled over lower Egypt from 715 b.c. (twenty-fifth Dynasty). His administration tried to extend his influence northward into the delta region.

verses.text: which sends envoys by sea in papyrus boats over the water. Go, swift messengers, to a people tall and smooth-skinned, to a people feared far and wide, an aggressive nation of strange speech, whose land is divided by rivers.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:2
rsbNotes.text:
18:2 vessels of papyrus. These are papyrus boats that the Nubians could use to send messengers to incite the nations to rebel against Assyria.

tall and smooth. The phrase possibly refers to the impressive appearance of the nation or nations that the remote Nubians were trying to stir up.

verses.text: All you people of the world, you who live on the earth, when a banner is raised on the mountains, you will see it, and when a trumpet sounds, you will hear it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:3
rsbNotes.text:
18:3 inhabitants of the world. Those addressed in this oracle will observe what the Lord is doing.

signal. See note 5:26. Trumpets were also commonly used as signals in war.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says to me: "I will remain quiet and will look on from my dwelling place, like shimmering heat in the sunshine, like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:4
rsbNotes.text:
18:4 I will quietly look . . . dwelling. Yahweh patiently observes the rebellion of the nations (Ps. 2:1–4).

clear heat . . . cloud of dew. Expressive of the stillness as God waits to act (see 25:5).

verses.text: For, before the harvest, when the blossom is gone and the flower becomes a ripening grape, he will cut off the shoots with pruning knives, and cut down and take away the spreading branches.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 18:5, 6 These verses contain two images of God’s judgment. First, there is the pruning of the vines before harvest to encourage the development of the grapes, “shoots” and “branches.” Second, there is the carcass on which the “birds of prey” and the wild animals feed. Contrast 31:5.

verses.text: They will all be left to the mountain birds of prey and to the wild animals; the birds will feed on them all summer, the wild animals all winter.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:6
rsbNotes.text: 18:6 summer . . . winter. The length of time implied emphasizes how extensive the carnage will be.

verses.text: At that time gifts will be brought to the LORD Almighty from a people tall and smooth-skinned, from a people feared far and wide, an aggressive nation of strange speech, whose land is divided by rivers- the gifts will be brought to Mount Zion, the place of the Name of the LORD Almighty.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 18:7
rsbNotes.text:
18:7 tribute. The nations offer tokens of submission (13:4 note; 16:1 note).

tall and smooth. See v. 2.

the place. The temple was the Old Testament token of God’s kingdom (Deut. 12:5, 11).
